Award.AwardTitle: Fall 2016 Mathematics Conference: Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
On September 23-24, 2016, the Department of Mathematics of Miami University at Oxford, Ohio, will hold its Forty-fourth Annual Mathematics Conference on the topic of Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems and their applications. An important feature of this conference is that in conjunction with it, on Friday, September 23, 2016, there will be a meeting devoted to research presentations by graduate and undergraduate students, celebrating the Ohio Delta Chapter of Pi Mu Epsilon (national mathematics student honor society). A new goal of this conference series is to introduce students to research in Applied Mathematics. The solicitation for contributed talks and the detailed information about the venue and the program will be posted at http://www.miamioh.edu/cas/academics/departments/mathematics/about/events/annual-mathematics-conference.

The conference will expose attendees to a broad range of topics through invited plenary talks on Climate Modeling, Game Theory, Fluid Dynamics and Applications of Control Theory to Aerial Robotics. A series of parallel contributed talks will provide the participants with the opportunity to present their results. The main goals of the conference are to expose students to cutting-edge research in the area of Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems, foster collaborations between researchers in Tri-state area (Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana), and encourage involvement of underrepresented minorities in mathematical research on this topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference on Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems and their Applications took place at Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, on September 23-24, 2017, in the framework of the 44th Annual Mathematics conference. It was held in conjunction with the Pi Mu Epsilon conference which is an undergraduate student research conference. Together the two conferences provided a venue for 27 mathematicians and 12 undergraduate students to present their research results and foster collaborations.

A total of 49 professional mathematicians at different stages of their careers and undergraduate 79 students, mostly from the Tri-State area (Ohio, Indiana, and Kentucky), attended the conference. The high number of participants indicates that the topic of the conference is of high interest for the mathematical community in the Tri-State area.

This NSF funded conference provided opportunities for junior researchers to obtain feedback on their projects. The conference featured several social events where students interacted with researchers and faculty members from the Tri-State area and beyond, and were able to inquire about graduate programs and careers in Mathematics and related areas. NSF funding was used to support students, attendees at the early stages of their careers, female and other underrepresented categories of participants, and researchers for whom other funding was not available.
